questions.text: Pheochromocytoma is a type of neuroendocrine tumour that grows from cells called chromaffin cells. These cells produce hormones needed for the body and are found in the adrenal glands. The classic "rule of tens" for phaeochromocytomas doesn't include?
questions.correct_answer: C. 10% of hypertensive patients harbour it
questions.explanation:
Solution:

10% of hypertensive patients harbour it Pheochromocytomas and paragangliomas are catecholamine-producing tumours derived from the sympathetic or parasympathetic nervous system. These tumours may arise sporadically or be inherited as features of multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 (men 2), von Hippel–Lindau (vhl) disease, or several other pheochromocytoma-associated syndromes its clinical presentation is so variable that pheochromocytoma has been termed “the great masquerader” (table 380-1). Among the presenting manifestations, episodes of palpitation, headache, and profuse sweating Are typical, and these manifestations constitute a classic triad. The presence of all three manifestations in association with hypertension makes pheochromocytoma a likely diagnosis ~0.1% of hypertensive patients harbour a pheochromocytoma .

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options A, B, and D: Include them . The classic “rule of tens” for phaeochromocytomas states that ~10% are bilateral, 10% are extra-adrenal, 10% are malignant.

questions.text: A patient presents with episodes of palpitation, profuse sweating and headache. On examination, BP is elevated. The MRI scan of the abdomen is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Phaeochromocytoma Its clinical presentation is so variable that pheochromocytoma has been termed “the great masquerade” . Among the presenting manifestations, episodes of palpitation, headache, and profuse sweating are typical, and these manifestations constitute a classic triad. The presence of all three manifestations in association with hypertension makes pheochromocytoma a likely diagnosis. The MRI shows typical pheochromocytoma (adrenal unilateral enhancement).

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Less likely as an abdominal mass on MRI . Option: B. Less likely and usually asymptomatic mass in Cushing. Option: D. Less likely as the MRI shows typical pheochromocytoma (adrenal unilateral).

questions.text: All of the following should be considered as Preoperative preparation of the patient with pheochromocytoma EXCEPT?

options.label: A
options.text: Liberal salt intake and hydration are necessary

options.label: B
options.text: Blood pressure should be consistently <130/80 mmHg

options.label: C
options.text: Oral prazosin or intravenous phentolamine can be used to manage paroxysms

options.label: D
options.text: Classically, blood pressure has been controlled by ?-adrenergic blockers

questions.correct_answer: B. Blood pressure should be consistently <130/80 mmHg
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Blood pressure should be consistently <130/80 mmHg Complete tumour removal, the ultimate therapeutic goal, can be achieved by partial or total adrenalectomy. It is important to preserve the normal adrenal cortex in order to prevent Addison’s disease, particularly in hereditary disorders in which bilateral pheochromocytomas are most likely. Preoperative preparation of the patient has to be considered, and blood pressure should be consistently < 160/90 mmHg.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A : Because patients are volume-constricted, liberal salt intake and hydration are necessary to avoid severe orthostasis. Option: C: Oral prazosin or intravenous phentolamine can be used to manage paroxysms while adequate alpha blockade is awaited. Option: D: Classically, blood pressure has been controlled by α-adrenergic blockers (oral phenoxybenzamine, 0.5–4 mg/kg of body weight).

questions.text: Which of the following is used to diagnose malignant pheochromocytoma?

options.label: C
options.text: Invasion of vessels or adjacent tissues

questions.correct_answer: D. Lymph node or distant metastases
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Lymph node or distant metastases About 5–10% of pheochromocytomas and paragangliomas are malignant. The term malignant pheochromocytoma is restricted to tumours with lymph nodes or distant metastases, the latter most commonly found by nuclear Medicine imaging in lungs, bone, or liver locations suggesting a vascular pathway of spread.

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options: A, B, C: The typical histologic criteria of cellular atypia, presence of mitoses, and invasion of vessels or adjacent tissues are insufficient for the diagnosis of malignancy in pheochromocytoma. Adrenal Disorders (Cushing syndrome and primary hyperaldosteronism)

questions.text: The patient 42 years old has features of enuresis and nocturia. 24-hour urine volume and osmolarity on restricted food intake were estimated. Volume was found to be greater than 40 ml per kg and osmolarity was found to be less than 300 mOsm/kg .basal plasma AVP was found to be less than 1 pg per ml .brain MRI was done to look for a pituitary bright spot which was absent .what is your diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pituitary diabetes insipidus This question is based on the simplified approach to the differential diagnosis of diabetes insipidus The clinical symptoms of urinary frequency and signs of enuresis are present Osmolarity is less than 300msom/l The volume is greater than 40 ml per kg per day Hence it is found that the patient has diabetes insipidus and should be evaluated further to determine the type and select the appropriate therapy Here it is given the basal plasma EVP was found to be less than 1 pg per ml This excludes nephrogenic diabetes as the answer Because in nephrogenic diabetes, the basal plasma AVP will be equal to 1pg/ml or it will be elevated Pituitary diabetes insipidus is also excluded because the bright spot is present. In this patient the bright spot is present Hence the diagnosis is primary polydipsia

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A nephrogenic diabetes insipidus This option is excluded because in nephrogenic di the basal plasma AVP is >1pg/ml Option: B pituitary diabetes insipidus This option is excluded because there is no bright spot present in the MRI of pituitary DI patients Option: D no diagnosis, perform the genitourinary evaluation This option is excluded because this is done when the volume is <40ml/kg and the osmolarity is >300mosm/l

There is an absence of glucosuria. 24-hour urine with normal fluid intake was evaluated. Osmolarity was less than 300 mOsm/kg and volume was greater than 50 ml per kg per day. What will you do next?

options.label: D

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Administer desmopressin It is given the patients have symptoms of urinary frequency and there is persistent thirst present in the absence of glucosuria the lab investigation of osmolarity less than 300 mOsm per kg and volume greater than 50 ml per kg, we have to go to the diagnosis of diabetes insipidus and the further causes of it The next step would be the administration of desmopressin because the signs and symptoms of uncomplicated pituitary diabetes insipidus can be eliminated by treatment with desmopressin

Extraedge:

Desmopressin is a synthetic analogue of AVP Desmopressin acts selectively at v2 receptors to increase urinary concentration and decreased urine flow in a dose-dependent manner It is also more resistant to degradation Consequently, the water balance is maintained within the normal range

questions.text: The patient is characterized by recurrent hypertonic dehydration. There is hypernatremia present along with signs of hypovolemia. The patient said that he had the same episode a few months back. What will you do next?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Administer water Here there is the patient is characterized by recurrent hypertonic dehydration along with the signs of hypovolemia This means the patient is having many episodes of this and also the patient is alert enough to say there she developed the same episode a few months back This points towards the diagnosis of hypertonic hypernatremia which is an increase in plasma osmolarity above the normal range. There can be caused by a decrease in total body water or an increase in total body volume The first step in the treatment should be by administering water only if the patient is alert and cooperative Here the patient has said that he had this episode a few months back This means the patient is alert enough and cooperative Hence the next step would be to administer water The deficit can be estimated from body weight in kg and the serum sodium

But in the question, there is no mention of hyperglycemia C. Hence this option is excluded Option: C potassium supplement Potassium supplements are used in the treatment of hypodipsic hypoxia when there are signs of hypokalemia present But in the question, there is no mention of hypokalemia Option: D perform an MRI Once the patient has been rehydrated, an MRI of the brain and a test of anterior pituitary function should be performed to look for the cause and collateral defects in other hypothalamic function

questions.text: In a male fetus, there are features of feminization. Breast development is normal. There is a short vagina and a uterus is absent. There are also features of cryptorchidism present. What is your diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Androgen insensitivity syndrome Here in this patient, the androgen receptors will not respond well to the androgen and this is the reason why there will be feminization of masculine features The person is male, there is the absence of a uterus However, there is normal breast development and there is a short vagina Testis usually is not present completely, hence there are features of cryptorchidism and this will present as a mass in the inguinal region

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A Congenital adrenal hyperplasia This is due to a deficiency of Steroidogenesis The patients are normotensive Ambiguous genitalia with clitoris enlargement and labial fusion and hyperpigmentation are the presenting features However, these are not mentioned in the question and hence this option is ruled out Option: B 5 alpha reductase deficiency This condition occurs in male Here testis will be in the normal position and this condition occurs in male There is also the absence of Mullerian structures Option: C Maternal Virilizing tumour This will cause masculinization of a female fetus But here in the question it is given that it is a male fetus And hence this option is excluded
